turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: What did you stop it for?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: I want you to take a good look at that face.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: George Bailey.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, you mean the kid that had his ears slapped back by the druggist.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: That's the kid.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: It's a good face. I like it. I like George Bailey. Tell me, did he ever tell anyone about the pills?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Not a soul.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Did he ever marry the girl? Did he ever go exploring?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Well, wait and see.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: I know. I know. He didn't go.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: That's right. Not only that, but he gave his school money to his brother Harry, and sent him to college. Harry became a football star  made second team All American.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, but what happened to George?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Now, you've probably already guessed that George never leaves Bedford Falls.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: . . . two of them as they were about to crash into a transport full of soldiers.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, but George . . .

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: You sent for me, sir?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, Clarence. A man down on earth needs our help.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Splendid! Is he sick?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: No, worse. He's discouraged. At exactly ten-forty-five PM tonight, Earth time, that man will be thinking seriously of throwing away God's greatest gift.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, dear, dear! His life! Then I've only got an hour to dress. What are they wearing now?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: You will spend that hour getting acquainted with George Bailey.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Sir . . . If I should accomplish this mission  I mean  might I perhaps win my wings? I've been waiting for over two hundred years now, sir  and people are beginning to talk.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: What's that book you've got there?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Clarence, you do a good job with George Bailey, and you'll get your wings.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh, thank you, sir. Thank you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey . . . hey. Where did the Building and Loan move to?

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: The Building and what?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: The Bailey Building and Loan. It was up there.

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: They went out of business years ago.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, Violet!  Hey, listen  that's Violet Bick!

turns.speaker: COP
turns.text: I know. I know.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know that girl!

turns.speaker: DR. CAMPBELL
turns.text: I want the Board to know that George gave up his trip to Europe to help straighten things out here these past few months. Good luck to you at school, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: DR. CAMPBELL
turns.text: Now we come to the real purpose of this meeting  to appoint a successor to our dear friend, Peter Bailey.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DR. CAMPBELL
turns.text: It was his faith and devotion that are responsible for this organization.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: DR. CAMPBELL
turns.text: That's the best part of it. They've appointed George here as executive secretary to take his father's place.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, no! But, Uncle Billy . . .

turns.speaker: DR. CAMPBELL
turns.text: You can keep him on. That's all right. As secretary you can hire anyone you like.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, Ernie!

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Hiya, George!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hi, Bert.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: If either of you two see a stranger around here, it's me.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, look! Somebody's driving this cab.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Bert, the cop, sent this over. He said to float away to Happy Land on the bubbles.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, look at this. Champagne!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Aw, now, doggone it, Ernie, don't you start pulling that stuff. You know where I live. Three-twenty Sycamore. Now hurry up.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Okay. Three-twenty Sycamore? . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah  yeah  hurry up. Zuzu's sick.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Look, bud, what's the idea? I live in a shack in Potter's Field and my wife ran away three years ago and took the kid . . . And I ain't never seen you before in my life.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Okay. Just step on it. Just get me home.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Is this the place?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Of course it's the place.

turns.speaker: ERNIE
turns.text: Well, this house ain't been lived in for twenty years.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Hello, Joseph, trouble?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Looks like we'll have to send someone down  a lot of people are asking for help for a man named George Bailey.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: George Bailey. Yes, tonight's his crucial night. You're right, we'll have to send someone down immediately. Whose turn is it?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: That's why I came to see you, sir. It's that clock-maker's turn again.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh  Clarence. Hasn't got his wings yet, has he? We've passed him up right along.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Because, you know, sir, he's got the I.Q. of a rabbit.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, but he's got the faith of a child  simple. Joseph, send for Clarence.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: On V-J Day he wept and prayed again.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN'S VOICE
turns.text: Joseph, now show him what happened today.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MA BAILEY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mother . . .

turns.speaker: MA BAILEY
turns.text: Mother? What do you want?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, Mother, Mother, please help me. Something terrible's happened to me. I don't know what it is. Something's happened to everybody. Please let me come in. Keep me here until I get over it.

turns.speaker: MA BAILEY
turns.text: Get over what? I don't take in strangers unless they're sent here by somebody I know.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, sure I do.

turns.speaker: MA BAILEY
turns.text: When'd you see him last?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Today, over at the house.

turns.speaker: MA BAILEY
turns.text: That's a lie. He's been in the insane asylum ever since he lost his business. And if you ask me, that's where you belong.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Hi, Daddy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, what happened to you?

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: I won a flower.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Wait now. Where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Want to give my flower a drink.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All right, all right. Here, give Daddy the flower. I'll give it a drink.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Look, Daddy . . . paste it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, all right. Now, I'll paste this together.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There it is, good as new.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Give the flower a drink.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Will you try to get some sleep?

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: I'm not sleepy. I want to look at my flower.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know  I know, but you just go to sleep, and then you can dream about it, and it'll be a whole garden.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: It will?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Daddy!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Zuzu  Zuzu. My little gingersnap! How do you feel?

turns.speaker: ZUZU
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, oh. Sam Wainwright! How are you? When did you get here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh, this afternoon. I thought I'd give the kids a treat.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Old college graduate now, huh?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah  old Joe College Wainwright, they call me. Well, freshman, looks like you're going to make it after all.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hee-haw!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hee-haw!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We just stopped in town to take a look at the new factory, and then we're going to drive on down to Florida.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, I'm afraid I couldn't get away, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Still got the nose to the old grindstone, eh? Jane, I offered to let George in on the ground floor in plastics, and he turned me down cold.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, now, don't rub it in.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm not rubbing it in. Well, I guess we better run along.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So long, George. See you in the funny papers.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Goodbye, Sam.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Big  see! I don't want one for one night. I want something for a thousand and one nights, with plenty of room for labels from Italy and Baghdad, Samarkand . . . a great big one.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I see, a flying carpet, huh? I don't suppose you'd like this old second-hand job, would you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now you're talkin'. Gee whiz, I could use this as a raft in case the boat sunk. How much does this cost?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No charge.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's my trick ear, Joe. It sounded as if you said no charge.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What boat you sailing on?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm working across on a cattle boat.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: A cattle boat?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: I own the house. Me, Giuseppe Martini. I own my own house. No more we live like pigs in thisa Potter's Field. Hurry, Maria.

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: Goodbye, everybody!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All in . . .

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: He's gone. Don't worry. His name is Welch. He don't come in to my place no more.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh  Welch. That's what I get for praying.

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: The last time he come in here. You hear that, Nick?

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: Oh, no, Please, don't go out this way, Mr. Bailey.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm all right.

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: Oh, no  you don't feel so good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm all right.

turns.speaker: MARTINI
turns.text: Please don't go away  please!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: She's swell.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Looks like she can keep Harry on his toes.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Keep him out of Bedford Falls, anyway.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Did you know that Mary Hatch is back from school?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Came back three days ago.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hmmmm . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Nice girl, Mary.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hmmmm . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Kind that will help you find the answers, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hmmm . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Oh, stop that grunting.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hmmm . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Can you give me one good reason why you shouldn't call on Mary?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sure  Sam Wainwright.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Hmmm?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes. Sam's crazy about Mary.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Well, she's not crazy about him.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, how do you know? Did she discuss it with you?

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well then, how do you know?

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Well, I've got eyes, haven't I? Why, she lights up like a firefly whenever you're around.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: And besides, Sam Wainwright's away in New York, and you're here in Bedford Falls.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And all's fair in love and war?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mother, you know, I can see right through you  right back to your back collar button . . . trying to get rid of me, huh?

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, here's your hat, what's your hurry? All right, Mother, old Building and Loan pal, I think I'll go out and find a girl and do a little passionate necking.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAILEY
turns.text: Oh, George!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now, if you'll just point me in the right direction . . . This direction?  Good night, Mrs. Bailey.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: George! George!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: You're not paid to be a canary.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Gower, do you want something . . . Anything?

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Anything I can do back here?

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, sir. They have the diphtheria there, haven't they, sir?

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Ummmm . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Is it a charge, sir?

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Yes  charge.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Gower, I think . . .

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Aw, get going!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: No . . . No . . . No. . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Don't hurt my ear again!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Gower, I won't ever tell anyone. I know what you're feeling. I won't ever tell a soul. Hope to die, I won't.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Oh, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Gower . . . Mr. Gower . . . thanks ever so much for the bag. It's just exactly what I wanted.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Aw, forget it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, it's wonderful.

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: Hope you enjoy it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mr. Gower! Mr. Gower! This is George Bailey! Don't you know me?

turns.speaker: GOWER
turns.text: No. No.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yes, you bet.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Where's my insurance policy?  Oh, here . . .

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You want a martini?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, no, Martini. Your boss. Where is he?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Okay  all right. Double bourbon, quick, huh?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Okay.  What's yours?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: That does it! Out you two pixies go, through the door or out the window!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, Nick. What's wrong?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, Nick, that's your name, isn't it?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What's that got to do with it? I don't know you from Adam's off ox.  Hey, you! Rummy! Come here! Come here!

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Hope you have a good trip, George. Uncle Billy and I are going to miss you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm going to miss you, too, Pop. What's the matter? You look tired.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Oh, I had another tussle with Potter today.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh . . .

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: I thought when we put him on the Board of Directors, he'd ease up on us a little bit.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I wonder what's eating that old money-grubbing buzzard anyway?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Oh, he's a sick man. Frustrated and sick. Sick in his mind, sick in his soul, if he has one. Hates everybody that has anything that he can't have. Hates us mostly, I guess.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Father, did I act like that when I graduated from high school?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Pretty much. You know, George, wish we could send Harry to college with you. Your mother and I talked it over half the night.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: We have that all figured out. You see, Harry'll take my job at the Building and Loan, work there four years, then he'll go.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: He's pretty young for that job.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, no younger than I was.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Maybe you were born older, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: I say, maybe you were born older. I suppose you've decided what you're going to do when you get out of college.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, well, you know what I've always talked about  build things . . . design new buildings  plan modern cities  all that stuff I was talking about.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Still after that first million before you're thirty.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, I'll settle for half that in cash.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: I know it's soon to talk about it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, now, Pop, I couldn't. I couldn't face being cooped up for the rest of my life in a shabby little office.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Yes . . . Yes . . . You're right, son.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You see what I mean, don't you, Pop?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: This town is no place for any man unless he's willing to crawl to Potter. You've got talent, son. You get yourself an education. Then get out of here.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Pop, do you want a shock? I think you're a great guy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm going to miss old Annie. Pop, I think I'll get dressed and go over to Harry's party.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Have a good time, son.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Got a match?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Very funny. Very funny.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you mean, and be bored to death?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Couldn't want a better death. Lots of pretty girls, and we're going to use that new floor of yours tonight, too.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I hope it works.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mary . . . Mary, I'm sorry. I've got to go.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Come on, George, let's hurry.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Did you get a doctor?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, am I glad to see you.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Say, where's Mother?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: She's home cooking the fatted calf. Come on, let's go.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, wait. Wait . . . Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hello, George, how are you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Harry . . . Harry . . .

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hiya, Marty. Well, it's old home week.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Do me a favor, will you, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Well, you remember my kid sister, Mary?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh . . . me? Oh, well, I feel funny enough already, with all these kids.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Aw, come on. Be a sport. Just dance with her one time and you'll give her the thrill of her life.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Two cents worth of shoelaces?

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: She was here first.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Bailey.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello, Violet. Hey, you look good. That's some dress you got on there.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Hey, George . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello, Violet.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Hello, what am I bid?

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Hello, Georgie-Porgie.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello, Vi.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: What gives?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Oh, I'll probably end up down at the library.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Let's go out in the fields and take off our shoes and walk through the grass.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Then we can go up to the falls. It's beautiful up there in the moonlight, and there's a green pool up there, and we can swim in it. Then we can climb Mt. Bedford, and smell the pines, and watch the sunrise against the peaks, and . . . we'll stay up there the whole night, and everybody'll be talking and there'll be a terrific scandal . . .

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: George, can I see you for a second?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why, of course you can. Come on in the office here.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: No, George, don't . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Here, now, you're broke, aren't you?

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: I know, but . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you want to do, hock your furs, and that hat? Want to walk to New York? You know, they charge for meals and rent up there just the same as they do in Bedford Falls.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Say hello to New York for me.

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: Yeah  yeah . . . sure I will.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now, let's hear from you . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Violet Bick!

turns.speaker: VIOLET
turns.text: I'm not going to go, George. I changed my mind.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Avast, there, Captain Cook! Where you headin'?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Got to see Pop, Uncle Billy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Some other time, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's important.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: There's a squall in there that's shapin' up into a storm.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Uh-huh. Breakfast is served; lunch is served; dinner . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, no, no, no! Anchor chains, plane motors, and train whistles.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Peanut?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Well, what do you know  wife.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, how do you do. Congratulations. Congratulations. What am I doing?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Oh, thank you, George, old boy, old boy. Now, look  if you'll point me in the right direction . . . would you do that? George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Right down here.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Old Building and Loan pal, huh . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now you just turn this way and go right straight down.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: That way, huh?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What is this, Uncle Billy? A holiday?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: George . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why didn't you call me?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: I just did, but they said you left. This is a pickle, George, this is a pickle.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All right now, what happened? How did it start?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: How does anything like this ever start? All I know is the bank called our loan.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: About an hour ago. I had to hand over all our cash.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All of it?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Every cent of it, and it still was less than we owe.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Holy mackerel!

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: And then I got scared, George, and closed the doors. I . . . I . . . I . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: The whole town's gone crazy.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Yes, hello? George . . . it's Potter.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: George, was it a nice wedding? Gosh, I wanted to be there.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah . . .  . . . you can take this one off now.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Those Rockefellers!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Get a tray for these great big important simoleons.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: We'll save them for seed. A toast!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now look, did you buy anything?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Nothing. Not even a stick of gum.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All right. All right. Now we'll go over every step you took since you left the house.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: This way.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And did you put the envelope in your pocket?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Yeah . . yeah . . . maybe . . . maybe . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Pop!

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Have you put any real pressure on those people of yours to pay those mortgages?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Pop!

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: They're not my children.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: You see, if you shoot pool with some employee here, you can come and borrow money. What does that get us? A discontented, lazy rabble instead of a thrifty working class. And all because a few starry-eyed dreamers like Peter Bailey stir them up and fill their heads with a lot of impossible ideas. Now, I say . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Just a minute  just a minute. Now, hold on, Mr. Potter. You're right when you say my father was no business man. I know that. Why he ever started this cheap, penny-ante Building and Loan, I'll never know. But neither you nor anybody else can say anything against his character, because his whole life was . . . Why, in the twenty-five years since he and Uncle Billy started this thing, he never once thought of himself. Isn't that right, Uncle Billy? He didn't save enough money to send Harry to school, let alone me. But he did help a few people get out of your slums, Mr. Potter. And what's wrong with that? Why . . . Here, you're all businessmen here. Doesn't it make them better citizens? Doesn't it make them better customers? You . . . you said . . . What'd you say just a minute ago? . . . They had to wait and save their money before they even ought to think of a decent home. Wait! Wait for what? Until their children grow up and leave them? Until they're so old and broken-down that they . . . Do you know how long it takes a working man to save five thousand dollars? Just remember this, Mr. Potter, that this rabble you're talking about . . . they do most of the working and paying and living and dying in this community. Well, is it too much to have them work and pay and live and die in a couple of decent rooms and a bath? Anyway, my father didn't think so. People were human beings to him, but to you, a warped, frustrated old man, they're cattle. Well, in my book he died a much richer man than you'll ever be!

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: I'm not interested in your book. I'm talking about the Building and Loan.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know very well what you're talking about. You're talking about something you can't get your fingers on, and it's galling you. That's what you're talking about, I know.  Well, I've said too much. I . . . You're the Board here. You do what you want with this thing. Just one thing more, though. This town needs this measly one-horse institution if only to have some place where people can come without crawling to Potter. Come on, Uncle Billy!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Thank you, sir. Quite a cigar, Mr. Potter.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: You like it? I'll send you a box.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes. Well, most people say you stole all the rest.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: The envious ones say that, George, the suckers. Now, I have stated my side very frankly. Now, let's look at your side. Young man, twenty-seven, twenty-eight . . . married, making, say . . . forty a week.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: You wouldn't mind living in the nicest house in town, buying your wife a lot of fine clothes, a couple of business trips to New York a year, maybe once in a while Europe. You wouldn't mind that, would you, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Would I?  You're not talking to somebody else around here, are you? You know, this is me, you remember me? George Bailey.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Oh, yes, George Bailey. Whose ship has just come in  providing he has brains enough to climb aboard.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, what about the Building and Loan?

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Oh, confound it, man, are you afraid of success? I'm offering you a three year contract at twenty thousand dollars a year, starting today. Is it a deal or isn't it?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, Mr. Potter, I . . . I . . . I know I ought to jump at the chance, but I . . . I just . . . I wonder if it would be possible for you to give me twenty-four hours to think it over?

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Sure, sure, sure. You go on home and talk about it to your wife.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'd like to do that.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: In the meantime, I'll draw up the papers.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All right, sir.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Have you notified the police?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, sir. I didn't want the publicity. Harry's homecoming tomorrow . . .

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, sir. No, sir. I haven't.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: What is it  a woman, then? You know, it's all over town that you've been giving money to Violet Bick.
